review: The Amazon Fire TV is pretty solid, but I wish it wasn't as proprietary as they make it.  Unlike their competitor Roku, the Amazon Fire TV will not let you compare the rates of a show or movie across multiple subscriptions (netflix, hulu, etc.  I really wish they would allow you to do this, as it would make the user experience way better and also promote willingness in integration.  Honestly, I am going to open up Netflix or Hulu if Amazon charges for the movie/tv show, so really it isn't saving them any money.  If Amazon has it free with my prime membership, just promote the video on their service in the master list; problem solved.Last, I think one of the coolest thigns with the Amazon Fire TV is the ability to sideload apps.  If you are willing to understand that an app isn't supported and are willing to do some homework, you can indeed put additional android apps on at your own discretion.  This allows the Amazon Fire TV to blow any other product out of the water.

review: I purchased the Amazon Fire TV for my Samsung Smart TV....yes I know, I shouldn't need it, but since upgrading my router for faster internet speed on Verizon Fios my Family Room Smart TV no longer will connect or if it does it won't keep the connect very long.  I have changed out the antenna's on the router and bought internet booster for each floor...and needless to say, Verizon is NO HELP!  This little, and I mean little box, has solved my issues.  It's easy to set up, works like a charm.
